title: Lists of Properties
narrative:
Just like properties you can create lists of properties
    and then bind them to UI components.
    They are a powerful tool to model the state
    as well as business logic of your UI without actually depending on it.
    This is especially useful for testing your UIs logic.
    This specification shows how to use the various
    methods exposed by the property lists classes,
    namely "Vals" (immutable) and "Vars" (mutable).

features.id: Multiple properties can be modelled through the "Vars" and "Vals" classes.

extraInfo:
Note: The `setAt` method replaces the properties at the given index with a new property.
            This is different to the `vars.at(index).set(value)` which updated the property itself.

A "Vals" class with two properties.
Both the "Vars" and "Vals" have two properties.
You can also use the "First" and "last" methods.
They also have the correct type.
The `Vals` class has no methods for mutation, it is read only (basically a tuple).
Both property lists are not empty
Both property lists are iterable
We change the state of the "Vars" properties.
The "Vars" properties have changed.
We use the "setAt" method to change the state of the "Vars" properties.
code: Note: The `setAt` method replaces the properties at the given index with a new property.
This is different to the `vars.at(index).set(value)` which updated the property itself.

features.id: You can set a range of properties to a given value or property with the `setRange` method.

features.id: You can remove n leading or trailing entries from a property list.

extraInfo:
A very common use case is to remove the first or last entry from a list.
            Not only can you do this with the "removeFirst()" and "removeLast()" methods,
            but you can also remove n entries from the start or end of the list
            through the "removeFirst(int)" and "removeLast(int)" methods.

blocks.text: A "Vars" class with six properties.
The "Vars" class has six properties.
We remove the first entry from the list.
The "Vars" class has five properties.
The first entry has been removed.
We remove the last entry from the list.
The "Vars" class has four properties.
The last entry has been removed.
We remove the first two entries from the list.
The "Vars" class has two properties.
The first two entries have been removed.
We remove the last two entries from the list.
The "Vars" class has no properties.

features.id: You can remove a range of entries from a property list.

extraInfo:
A common use case is to remove a range of entries from a list.
            You can remove not only the first or the last `n` entries with the `removeFirst(int)` and `removeLast(int)`
            methods. You can also remove entries within the range of any two indices with the
            `removeRange(int, int)` method.

blocks.text: A `Vars` instance with six properties.
The `Vars` instance has six properties.
We remove the two entries between index `1` and index `3` from the list.
The `Vars` instance has four properties.
The two entries have been removed.

features.id: You can remove a sequence of `n` entries from a property list.

extraInfo:
A common use case is to remove a sequence of entries from a list.
            You can remove not only the first or the last `n` entries with the `removeFirst(int)` and `removeLast(int)`
            methods. You can also remove `n` entries starting at any index with the `removeAt(int, int)` method.

blocks.text: A `Vars` instance with six properties.
The `Vars` instance has six properties.
We remove the two entries starting at index `1` from the list.
The `Vars` instance has four properties.
The two entries have been removed.

features.id: The properties of one property list can be added to another property list.

extraInfo:
The properties of one property list can be added to another property list.
            This is useful when you want to combine two property lists into one.

features.id: A list of properties can be turned into lists, sets or maps using various convenience methods.

extraInfo:
The "Vals" class has a number of convenience methods for turning the list of properties into
            immutable lists, sets or maps. 
            These methods make property lists more compatible with the rest of the Java ecosystem.

blocks.text: A "Vars" class with 4 properties that have unique ids.
We turn the list of properties into different collection types...
The collections have the correct size and values.
All of these collections are of the correct type.

features.id: A list of properties can be turned into an immutable "Vals" list using the "toVals" method.

blocks.text: A "Vars" class with 4 properties that have unique ids.
We turn the list of properties into an immutable "Vals" list.
The "Vals" list has the correct size and values.

features.id: The "makeDistinct" method on a mutable list of properties modifies the list in-place.

extraInfo:
The `makeDistinct` method makes sure that there are only unique values in the Vals list.
            It does this by removing all duplicates from the list.
            This is especially useful when you use the properties to model 
            combo box or radio button selections.
            This modification will be reported to all "show" listeners,
            which are usually used to update the UI.

blocks.text: A "Vars" class with 4 properties that have unique ids.
We register a listener which will record changes for us.
We call the "makeDistinct" method.
The list has been modified in-place.
The "show" listeners have been called.

features.id: Leading and trailing items can be popped off a property list.

extraInfo:
Methods with a "pop" prefix allow you to remove and then get the removed properties from a property list.
            This is useful when you want to remove a property from a list and then use it in some other way.
            In this feature we will look at the "popFirst" and "popLast" methods.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having 12 properties.
We pop the first and last property from the list.
The first and last properties have been removed from the list.
We removed properties have the correct values.
We pop the first and last 2 properties from the list.
The first and last 2 properties have been removed from the list.
We removed properties have the correct values.

features.id: You can pop a range of entries from a property list.

extraInfo:
To remove a range of properties and get the removed properties you can use the `popRange` method.
            This can be seen as a generalization of the `popFirst` and `popLast` methods.

blocks.text: A `Vars` instance with six properties of fallacy names.
code: var fallacies = Vars.of("Ad Hominem", "Naturalistic Fallacy", "Tu Quoque", "Red Herring", "Appeal to Tradition", "Strawman")

blocks.text: The `Vars` instance has six properties.
We pop the two entries between index `1` and index `3` from the list.
The popped `Vars` instance has two properties.
The popped `Vars` instance contains the expected values.

features.id: You can pop a sequence of `n` entries from a property list.

extraInfo:
To remove a sequence of properties and get the removed properties you can use the `popAt` method.
            This can be seen as a generalization of the `popFirst` and `popLast` methods.

blocks.text: A `Vars` instance with six properties.
The `Vars` instance has six properties.
We pop the two entries starting at index `1` from the list.
The popped `Vars` instance has two properties.
The popped `Vars` instance contains the expected values.

features.id: The "popAt" method return the removed property.

extraInfo:
The "popAt" method removes the property at the given index and returns it.
            If the index is out of bounds, an exception is thrown.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We pop the property at index 2.
The property at index 2 has been removed from the list.
The removed property has the correct value.

features.id: Use "removeOrThrow" to to guarantee the removal of a property.

extraInfo:
The "removeOrThrow" method removes the given property from the list.
            If the property is not in the list, an exception is thrown.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We remove the property at index 2.
No exception is thrown.
The property at index 2 has been removed from the list.
We try to remove a property that is not in the list.
An exception is thrown.

features.id: Properties can be removed from a property list using a predicate.

extraInfo:
The "removeIf" method removes all properties from the list that match the given predicate.
            The method returns the original list to allow for chaining.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We remove all properties that start with "p".
The properties that start with "p" have been removed from the list.

features.id: Properties can be popped off a property list using a predicate.

extraInfo:
The "popIf" method removes all properties from the list that match the given predicate.
            The method returns a list of the removed properties.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We remove all properties that start with "p".
The properties that start with "p" have been removed from the list.
The removed properties have the correct values.

features.id: Items can be popped off a property list using a predicate.

extraInfo:
The "popIfItem" method removes all items from the list that match the given predicate.
            The method returns a list of the removed properties.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We remove all properties that start with "p".
The properties that start with "p" have been removed from the list.
The removed properties have the correct values.

features.id: Items can be removed from a property list using a predicate.

extraInfo:
The "removeIfItem" method removes all items from the list that match the given predicate.
            The method returns the original list to allow for chaining.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
We remove all properties that start with "p".
The properties that start with "p" have been removed from the list.

features.id: Using "addAll" to add multiple things to a property list will only trigger the change listeners once!

extraInfo:
The "addAll" method adds all the given properties to the list.
            The method returns the original list to allow for method chaining.
            Although the method adds multiple properties, causing multiple changes to the list,
            it will only trigger the change listeners once.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
A change listener that counts the number of changes.
We add multiple properties to the list.
The properties have been added to the list.
The change listener has only been triggered once.

features.id: Checkout these cool one liners!

extraInfo:
The "Vars" class has a nice API with many useful methods whose
             usage can be demonstrated in a single line of code.
             Let's have a look at some of them.

blocks.text:
Because `Var` and `Vars` are mutable, their equality is modelled in
            terms of their identity, not their value. Whereas `Val` and `Vals`
            are immutable, so their equality is modelled in terms of their value.

features.id: Various kinds of methods that mutate a property list will only trigger an "onChange" event once, even if multiple items are affected. [0]

extraInfo:
The purpose of the "onChange" event is to notify listeners that the list has changed.
            Typically, a listener will update the UI to reflect the new state of the list.
            However, if many items are changed at once, it is wasteful to update the UI multiple times.
            Therefore, the "onChange" event is only triggered once, even if multiple items are changed.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
A change listener that counts the number of changes.
We mutate the list using the given mutator.
The change listener has only been triggered once.

features.id: Various kinds of methods that mutate a property list will only trigger an "onChange" event once, even if multiple items are affected. [20]

extraInfo:
The purpose of the "onChange" event is to notify listeners that the list has changed.
            Typically, a listener will update the UI to reflect the new state of the list.
            However, if many items are changed at once, it is wasteful to update the UI multiple times.
            Therefore, the "onChange" event is only triggered once, even if multiple items are changed.

blocks.text: A "Vars" instance having a few properties.
A change listener that counts the number of changes.
We mutate the list using the given mutator.
The change listener has only been triggered once.

The `indexOf` method returns the index of the first occurrence of the given property.

features.id: You can easily create an empty "Vals" list.

extraInfo:
A common use case for empty lists and nullable empty lists is inside the change delegate.
            A delegate holds information about the change, such as the `newValues` and `oldValues`.
            These can also be empty. For example, when a property is removed from the list, the newVals list is empty.

blocks.text: A "Vals" and a nullable "Vals" instance with no properties.
The `size` method returns 0 and the `isEmpty` method returns true.
The `type` methods of the empty lists still return the correct type, even though they are empty.

features.id: The change delegate contains information about changes made to a "Vars" list by adding properties.

extraInfo:
When you add a property to a "Vars" list, the change delegate contains information about the change.
            The `newValues` of the delegate contains the added property, and the `oldValues` is always an empty list.

The `index` of the change points to the added property.

features.id: You can add properties to a nullable "Vars" list that from an immutable property list.

extraInfo:
A nullable "Vars" list is able to handle null values. 
            So you can add an immutable nullable property list to it.
            Under the hood, the immutable properties will be added
            to the list in the form of mutable properties.

features.id: You can create a mapped version of a property list.

extraInfo:
The `mapTo` method allows you to create a mapped list where all non-empty properties are mapped using a
            given mapping function. Empty properties are not mapped and will be reflected as empty properties in the
            resulting list, regardless of the mapping function.
            Note: The resulting property list is not a live view of the property list and will not update if the
            original list or its properties change.

blocks.text: A nullable "Vars" instance with some properties.
Map all non-nullable properties using a mapper function.
The resulting list contains the mapped properties.

features.id: Create a copy of the current state of the "Vars" list.

extraInfo:
A copy of the current state of a "Vars" list can be easily made using the `toVals' method.
            The copy captures the current state, and later changes to the underlying list will not be reflected in the copy.

blocks.text: A nullable and a non-nullable "Vars" instance with some properties.
Create copies of the current "Vars" instances using the `toVars` method.
The resulting lists should be equal to the original lists.
Also the nullability of the copied lists is equal to the original lists.
We can modify the underlying list.
Changes are not applied to copied lists, and the lists remain unchanged.

features.id: Immutable property lists are considered equal if their values are equal.

extraInfo:
The equality of two property lists is determined by the equality of their values,
            if and only if the lists are immutable.

blocks.text: We create a hand full of different types of property lists:
The immutable property lists are equal because their values are equal.
The mutable property lists on the other hand are not equal.
The mutable and immutable property lists are also never equal.

features.id: A nullable property list does not accept non-nullable properties.

extraInfo:
A nullable (and mutable) property list does not accept non-nullable properties.
            Which is to say that when you try to add a non-nullable property to a nullable property list,
            then the property list will throw an exception.

blocks.text: A nullable and mutable property list.
We implicitly add a property through a simple item.
No exception is thrown and the property is added.
We explicitly add a nullable property through a simple item.
Again, no exception is thrown and the property is added.
The property list has the expected values.
We now try to add a non-nullable property through a simple item.
An exception is thrown because the property list does not accept non-nullable properties.

features.id: A non-nullable property list does not accept nullable properties.

extraInfo:
A non-nullable (and mutable) property list does not accept nullable properties.
            Which is to say that when you try to add a nullable property to a non-nullable property list,
            then the property list will throw an exception.

blocks.text: A non-nullable and mutable property list.
We implicitly add a property through a simple item.
No exception is thrown and the property is added.
We explicitly add a non-nullable property through a simple item.
Again, no exception is thrown and the property is added.
The property list has the expected values.
We now try to add a nullable property through a simple item.
An exception is thrown because the property list does not accept nullable properties.

features.id: You cannot construct a non-nullable property list from nullable properties.

extraInfo:
You cannot construct a non-nullable property list from a nullable property list.
            Which is to say that when you try to call the `of` method on the `Vars` class with 
            set of nullable properties, then the property list will throw an exception.

blocks.text: We create a hand of properties, one of which is nullable.
We try to construct a non-nullable property list from the properties.
An exception is thrown because the property list does not accept nullable properties.

features.id: You cannot construct a nullable property list from non-nullable properties.

extraInfo:
You cannot construct a nullable property list from a non-nullable property list.
            Which is to say that when you try to call the `ofNullable` method on the `Vars` class with 
            set of non-nullable properties, then the property list will throw an exception.

blocks.text: We create a hand of properties, all of which are non-nullable.
We try to construct a nullable property list from the properties.
An exception is thrown because the property list does not accept non-nullable properties.

features.id: The `is(Vals)` method checks if the items of the current property list are equal to the other property list.

extraInfo:
The `is(Vals)` method checks if the items of the current property list are equal to the other property list.
            The method returns `true` if the items of the two property lists are equal, and `false` otherwise.

features.id: Use `all(Predicate)` to check if all properties in the list satisfy a given predicate.

extraInfo:
The `all(Predicate)` method uses the stream API to check if the
            properties in the list satisfy a given predicate.
            The method returns `true` if the predicate is satisfied by all properties, 
            and `false` otherwise.

features.id: The `removeOrThrow(Val)` method removes the given property from the list or throws an exception if the property is not in the list.

extraInfo:
The `removeOrThrow(Val)` method ensures that the given property is removed from the list
            only if the property is in the list. If the property is not in the list, an exception is thrown.

blocks.text: A property list with some properties.
We remove a property that is in the list.
The property is removed from the list.
We try to remove a property that is not in the list.
An exception is thrown because the property is not in the list.

features.id: Calling `.removeOrThrow(Var.of(..))` will always throw an exception.

extraInfo:
The difference between a `Val.of(..)` and a `Var.of(..)` is that the 
            former is an immutable value based property and the latter is a mutable
            reference based property. The `removeOrThrow` method will only remove
            a property if the exact same property is in the list or 
            an immutable value based property with the same value is in the list.

blocks.text: A property list with some properties.
We try to remove a property that is in the list.
An exception is thrown because the property is not in the list.
We try to remove a property by value that is in the list.
The property is removed from the list.
We remove a property that is actually in the list.
The property is removed from the list.

features.id: You can create a nullable immutable property list from nullable properties only.

extraInfo:
You can create a nullable immutable property list from nullable properties only.
            Which is to say that when you try to call the `of` method on the `Vals` class with 
            set of nullable properties, then the property list will accept the properties.

blocks.text: We create a hand of properties, all of which are nullable.
We try to construct a nullable property list from the first two properties.
No exception is thrown because the property list accepts nullable properties.
The property list has the expected values.
We try to construct a nullable property list from all three properties.
An exception is thrown because the property list does not accept non-nullable properties.

features.id: Use `addAt(int,Val)` to set the item as a new property and use `addAt(int,Var)` to set the supplied property.

extraInfo:
The `Vars` property list exposes two overloaded methods to set a property at a given index.
            The `addAt(int, Val)` method adds the item wrapped in a new independent property, while the
            `addAt(int, Var)` method actually takes the supplied property reference and then 
            puts it in the list at the given index.

            The reason why the `addAt(int, Val)` creates a copy of the property is because the `Val`
            type is a read only view on a potentially mutable `Var` property. So an API consumer
            expects that it's state is encapsulated and not affected by changes to the original property.

            In this example we demonstrate this difference by adding a simple property
            with a change listener to the list and then setting the property at a given index
            using both methods.

blocks.text: A simple String based property with a listener and a list tracking changes.
A property list with some japanese food properties.
code: var foods = Vars.of("寿司", "ラーメン", "カレー", "うどん", "おにぎり")

blocks.text: We use the two different methods to add the question mark property in the list.
The property is added to the list and the property did not change.
code: foods.toList() == ["寿司", "?", "ラーメン", "?", "カレー", "うどん", "おにぎり"]

blocks.text: We change the property item at index 1...
The property at index 1 is changed but the initial property did not change.
code: foods.toList() == ["寿司", "!", "ラーメン", "?", "カレー", "うどん", "おにぎり"]

blocks.text: We change the property item at index 3...
The property at index 3 is changed, and this time the initial property changed as well.
code: foods.toList() == ["寿司", "!", "ラーメン", "!", "カレー", "うどん", "おにぎり"]

features.id: Use `setAt(int,Val)` to set the item as a new property and use `setAt(int,Var)` to set the supplied property.

extraInfo:
The `Vars` property list exposes two overloaded methods to set a property at a given index.
            The `setAt(int, Val)` method adds the item wrapped in a new independent property, while the
            `setAt(int, Var)` method actually takes the supplied property reference and then 
            puts it in the list at the given index.

            The reason why the `setAt(int, Val)` creates a copy of the property is because the `Val`
            type is a read only view on a potentially mutable `Var` property. So an API consumer
            expects that it's state is encapsulated and not affected by changes to the original property.

            In this example we demonstrate this difference by adding a simple property
            with a change listener to the list and then setting the property at a given index
            using both methods.

blocks.text: A simple String based property with a listener and a list tracking changes.
A property list with some japanese food properties.
code: var foods = Vars.of("寿司", "ラーメン", "カレー", "うどん", "おにぎり")

blocks.text: We use the two different methods to add the question mark property in the list.
The property is added to the list and the property did not change.
We change the property item at index 1...
The property at index 1 is changed but the initial property did not change.
We change the property item at index 3...
The property at index 3 is changed, and this time the initial property changed as well.

features.id: Use `addAll(Vals)` to add the items as a new properties and use `addAll(Vars)` to add them unchanged.

extraInfo:
The `Vars` property list exposes two overloaded methods to add a list of properties.
            The `addAll(Vals)` method adds the items wrapped in new independent properties, while the
            `addAll(Vars)` method actually takes the supplied properties and then 
            puts them in the list unchanged.

            The reason why the `addAll(Vals)` creates a copy of the properties is because the `Vals`
            type is a read only view on a potentially mutable `Vars` property list. So an API consumer
            expects that it's state is encapsulated and not affected by changes to the original property list.

            In this example we demonstrate this difference by adding a simple property
            with a change listener to the list and then adding a list of properties
            using both methods.

blocks.text: Two simple String based properties with listeners and a list tracking changes.
A property list with some indian food properties.
A short list containing a the two properties.
We use the two different methods to add the properties in the list.
The properties are added to the list and the properties did not change.
We modify the items at index 2 and 3...
The properties at index 2 and 3 are changed but the initial properties did not change.
We change the property item at index 4 and 5 on the other hand...
The properties at index 4 and 5 are changed as well as the initial properties.

features.id: Use `addAllAt(int, Vals)` to add the items as a new properties and use `addAllAt(int, Vars)` to add them unchanged.

extraInfo:
The `Vars` property list exposes two overloaded methods to add a list of properties at a given index.
            The `addAllAt(int, Vals)` method adds the items wrapped in new independent properties, while the
            `addAllAt(int, Vars)` method actually takes the supplied properties and then 
            puts them in the list unchanged.

            The reason why the `addAllAt(int, Vals)` creates a copy of the properties is because the `Vals`
            type is a read only view on a potentially mutable `Vars` property list. So an API consumer
            expects that it's state is encapsulated and not affected by changes to the original property list.

            In this example we demonstrate this difference by adding a simple property
            with a change listener to the list and then adding a list of properties
            using both methods.

blocks.text: Two simple String based properties with listeners and a list tracking changes.
A property list with some indian food properties.
A short list containing a the two properties.
We use the two different methods to add the properties in the list.
The properties are added to the list and the properties did not change.
We modify the items at index 2 and 4...
The properties at index 1 and 2 are changed but the initial properties did not change.
We change the property item at index 3 and 5 on the other hand...
The properties at index 3 and 4 are changed as well as the initial properties.

features.id: Use `setAllAt(int, Vals)` to set items as new properties and use `setAllAt(int, Vars)` to set them unchanged.

extraInfo:
The `Vars` property list exposes two overloaded methods to replace a sequence properties starting
            at a given index. The `setAllAt(int, Vals)` method adds the items wrapped in new independent properties, 
            while the `setAllAt(int, Vars)` method actually takes the supplied properties and then 
            puts them in the list unchanged.

            The reason why the `setAllAt(int, Vals)` creates a copy of the properties is because the `Vals`
            type is a read only view on a potentially mutable `Vars` property list. So an API consumer
            expects that it's state is encapsulated and not affected by changes to the original property list.

            In this example we demonstrate this difference by adding a simple property
            with a change listener to the list and then adding a list of properties
            using both methods.

            Note that `setAllAt` is different from `addAllAt` in that it replaces the properties at the given index
            whereas `addAllAt` adds the properties at the given index (so the list grows).

blocks.text: Two simple String based properties with listeners and a list tracking changes.
A property list with some random string based properties.
A short list containing a the two properties.
We use the two different methods to set the properties in the list.
The properties are added to the list and the properties did not change.
We modify the items at index 2 and 4...
The properties at index 1 and 2 are changed but the initial properties did not change.
We change the property item at index 3 and 5 on the other hand...
The properties at index 3 and 4 are changed as well as the initial properties.

features.id: Using `addAt(int,Val)`, you can add a nullable property to a non-nullable list if the item is present.

extraInfo:
The `addAt(int, Val)` method is designed to ensure that the value
            of a property is added to a property list in the form of a new independent property.
            This means that as long as the value of the property is not null, the property can be added
            to a non-nullable property list.

blocks.text: A non-nullable property list and a nullable property.
We add the nullable property to the list.
The property is added to the list.
We change the value of the nullable property.
The property in the list is not affected.
We add the nullable property to the list at another index.
The property is added to the list.

We now try to add null to the property list by setting
            the nullable property to null and adding it to the list.
An exception is thrown because the property is null.

features.id: Using `setAt(int,Val)`, you can place the item of a nullable property into a non-nullable list if the item is present.

extraInfo:
The `setAt(int, Val)` method is designed to ensure that the value
            of a property is placed into a property list in the form of a new independent property.
            This means that as long as the value of the property is not null, the property can be placed
            into a non-nullable property list.

blocks.text: A non-nullable property list and a nullable property.
We set the nullable property at an index in the list.
The property is placed in the list.
We change the value of the nullable property.
The property in the list is not affected.
We set the nullable property at another index in the list.
The property is placed in the list.

We now try to set null to the property list by setting
            the nullable property to null and adding it to the list.
An exception is thrown because the property is null.

features.id: A non-null property list can accept a nullable list through "addAll(Vals)" as long as there are no nulls in the list.

extraInfo:
The `addAll(Vals)` method is designed to ensure that the values
            of a property list are added to another property list in the form of new independent properties.
            This always works as long as there is no null-item in the list
            passed to the `addAll` method.

            Note that this is different to `addAll(Vars)`, which will add the properties
            as they are, without creating new independent properties,
            and so will throw an exception if it has a different null-ness...

blocks.text: A non-nullable property list and a nullable property list.
We add the nullable property list to the list by upcasting it to a `Vals` type.
The properties are added to the list.

We now try to add null to the property list by setting
            one of the nullable properties to null and adding it to the list.
An exception is thrown because of this null item.

features.id: The various `setAllAt(int,..)` methods can throw index out of bounds exceptions.

extraInfo:
If you use the `setAllAt(int,..)` methods to set a range of properties at a given index,
            then you can get an `IndexOutOfBoundsException` if the index together with the size of the
            properties to set, exceeds the size of the targeted property list.

blocks.text: A property list with some properties.
We try to exceed the size by supplying a var args array that is too large.
An exception is thrown because the last index is out of bounds.
We try to exceed the size by supplying a `Vals` list that is too large.
An exception is thrown because the last index is out of bounds.
We try to exceed the size by supplying a `Vars` list that is too large.
An exception is thrown because the last index is out of bounds.
We try to set a range of items at an index that is out of bounds.
An exception is thrown because the start index is out of bounds.

features.id: The `remove(..)` methods remove all matching occurrences of a property from the list.

extraInfo:
The `remove(..)` methods remove all matching occurrences of a property from the list.
            The `remove(..)` methods are overloaded to accept both `Val` and `Var` properties.

blocks.text: A property list with some properties.
We use the `remove(T)` method to remove all occurrences of a property.
All occurrences of the property are removed from the list.
We use the `remove(Var<T>)` method to remove all occurrences of a property.
All occurrences of the property are removed from the list.
We try to remove a property which is not in the list but has an item that is in the list...
The list remains unchanged.
